<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 568, 89]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 106, 784, 123]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 154, 675, 171]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 202, 685, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 247, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 294, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 348, 656, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 368, 562, 401]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 444, 225, 460]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 905, 476]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 523]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 555, 220, 570]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 670, 592]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 630, 220, 645]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 572, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 740, 160, 755]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 737, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \sin^2 A + \cos^2 A &= 1 \\ \sec^2 A &= 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A &= 1 + \cot^2 A \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 829, 241, 845]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 822, 578, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \frac{a}{\sin A} &= \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 &= b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta &= \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 72, 665, 90]]<|/det|>
<form>Calculators must not be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 114, 99, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 114, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 102, 589, 135]]<|/det|>
(a) Given that \(\overrightarrow{P Q}=\left(\begin{array}{r}{-3} \\ {7}\end{array}\right)\) and \(4 \overrightarrow{P R}=\left(\begin{array}{r}{-2} \\ {8}\end{array}\right)\), find \(\overrightarrow{R Q}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 425, 144, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 422, 918, 456]]<|/det|>
(b) The vectors \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\) are such that \(\mathbf{a}=\alpha \mathbf{i}+6 \mathbf{j}, \quad \mathbf{b}=4 \mathbf{i}+\beta \mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{c}=(2 \alpha+5 \beta) \mathbf{i}+20 \mathbf{j}\), where \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are scalars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 467, 564, 485]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{c}=3 \mathbf{a}-2 \mathbf{b}\), find the values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 368, 91]]<|/det|>
3 Point \(A\) has coordinates \((3,-1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 98, 470, 121]]<|/det|>
A circle has equation \(\left(x-4\right)^{2}+\left(y+3\right)^{2}=5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 140, 144, 157]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 138, 556, 157]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(A\) lies on the circumference of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 263, 144, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 262, 675, 280]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that \(A B\) is a diameter of the circle, find the coordinates of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 618, 144, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 617, 544, 635]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the equation of the tangent to the circle at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 82, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 82, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 78, 411, 98]]<|/det|>
4 (a) Solve the equation \(x^{\frac{1}{3}} - x^{\frac{1}{6}} = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 407, 144, 423]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 406, 420, 422]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the simultaneous equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 425, 567, 462]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \lg (x+2 y)=0 \\
& x^{2}+4 x y+y=1
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 78, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 465, 95]]<|/det|>
5 \(\left|2 x-1\right|+8=23\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 78, 920, 95]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 278, 144, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 277, 700, 295]]<|/det|>
(b) On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y=5 \sin x-2\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 325, 787, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 90, 99, 107]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 420, 116]]<|/det|>
6 A curve has equation \(y=\left(\frac{x^{2}-1}{x^{2}+1}\right)^{4}\)  .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 128, 144, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 120, 850, 170]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\) can be written as \(\frac{A x\left(x^{2}-1\right)^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{5}}\) , where \(A\) is a positive integer to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 78, 185, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 76, 764, 95]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) Show that the curve has stationary points where \(x=-1, x=0\) and \(x=1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 200, 188, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 199, 918, 233]]<|/det|>
(ii) Use the first derivative test to determine which two stationary points have the same nature and state whether they are maximum or minimum points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 677, 91]]<|/det|>
7 Solutions to this question by accurate drawing will not be accepted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 95, 863, 115]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinates of the points where the curve \(y=(2 x-9)\left(x^{2}+5\right)+42\) cuts the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 78, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 678, 95]]<|/det|>
8 (a) Write down the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\log _{5}(12 x-4)\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 170, 144, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 163, 546, 193]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the equation \(\log _{5}(12 x-4)=\frac{6}{\log _{5}125}+1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
9

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 92, 765, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 450, 616, 467]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) with \(x\)-coordinate 2 lies on the curve \(y=\sqrt{4 x+1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 466, 668, 483]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of this curve and the tangent to the curve at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 496, 769, 514]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the curve, the tangent and the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 465, 90]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 83, 116, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 83, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 850, 112]]<|/det|>
10 (a) Given that \(0 \leqslant \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\) , show that \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\sqrt{\cos \mathrm{e}^{2} \theta - 1}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \tan ^{2} \theta}}\) can be written as \(\sec \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 501, 144, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 492, 710, 521]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that \(\sec x=\alpha\), where \(\frac{3 \pi}{2}<x \leqslant 2 \pi\), find \(\sin x\) in terms of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 74, 530, 91]]<|/det|>
11 An arithmetic progression has common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 89, 420, 107]]<|/det|>
The 3rd term of this progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 120, 759, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Write down expressions for the 1st term and the 2nd term of this progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 452, 153]]<|/det|>
Give your answers in terms of \(d\) only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 291, 144, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 289, 737, 307]]<|/det|>
(b) When each of the first 3 terms is squared, the sum of these squares is 140 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 305, 435, 323]]<|/det|>
There are two possible values for \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 336, 918, 369]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to part (a), find the sum of the first 200 terms of the progression with the smaller value of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 109, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 76, 303, 91]]<|/det|>
12 In this question \(n \geqslant 6\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 88, 730, 108]]<|/det|>
Use an algebraic method to show that \(^{n} C_{5}-^{n-1} C_{5}\) can be written as \(^{n-1} C_{4}\).
